Mass. state universities
to raise student fees this fall

Students who attend most Massachusetts state universities will have to pay more in the next academic year as schools increase annual fees. (Boston Globe)
  • 6/21: UMass Law to freeze tuition, fees for three years
  • 6/6: UMass trustees vote to increase tuition, fees | More

T hikes trigger mixed reactions

Some are upset, others resigned to a fare increase that's part of a package including service cuts that will keep the transit agency solvent for one more year. (Globe)

Era of the MBTA token to end

This time, the MBTA says, the token will be gone for good. As of July 20 the discs will no longer be valid and the T's stash will be headed for the blast furnace. (Boston Globe)

Transgender rights
law takes effect

Ethan St. Pierre, who began life as woman, said he was fired because he is transgendered, and he said the new law is a welcome step. (Boston Globe)

Residents tour Colo. blaze devastation

Residents returned to the area for the first time since fleeing flames last week, seeing only concrete left from many homes after the state's worst wildfire. (AP)

Mitt Romney’s education
record was mixed in Mass.

A review of Romney’s efforts as governor to impose changes reveals a wide disconnect between what he says on the stump and what he accomplished.
Opinion | Juliette Kayyem

Wildfires, politics, and other disasters

Colorado is finding that the politics of a campaign are made more caustic by the politics of disaster.

Digital used record store faces suit

The case involving Cambridge’s ReDigi.com, the Web’s first consignment shop for digital music, could end with a landmark decision on copyright law.

Can house calls cut health costs?

A Boston program is one of 16 in the US that is testing whether doctor visits can save money over the long run while improving health.

At 90, Raytheon faces new challenges

To survive the coming era of big cuts in military spending, the Waltham defense contractor will have to rely on its legacy of innovation.
Opinion | Jennifer Graham

The Bambi problem in Weston

We have too many deer, but, thanks in part to the cartoon image of the famous Disney fawn, we can’t bring ourselves to cull them.

Ailing pets get stem cell aid

Entrepreneurs have built a market of veterinary treatments, including pet massage, acupuncture, and even pricey stem cell treatments.
